newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft partners to launch Windows devices.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft partners to launch Windows devices.

text.p: Microsoft Corp. said Sunday more than 90 software and hardware vendors would have products available by April 1997 based on its new Windows CE operating system for handheld devices.
Casio Computer Co., Compaq Computer Corp. and NEC Corp. were expected to have the first handheld computers based on the new operating system available at retail stores Monday.

In addition to the operating system, a stripped-down version of Windows 95, the 16-ounce "pocketable" devices will include versions of Microsoft word processing and spreadsheet software as well as a personal information manager and in-box for electronic mail.
The initial devices were expected to retail for $500 to $700 including software and cables allowing users to synchronize data between their handheld and desktop computers.

"The introduction of the handheld PC with Windows CE is a critical milestone in Microsoft's continuing strategy to bring the popularity and ease of use to Windows to new categories of information devices," Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates said in a statement at the start of Comdex, the huge industry trade show.

The handheld computers all will include a stylus and touchscreen navigation system as well as a tiny keyboard for entering data and will be powered by AA batteries that should last for at least two weeks of normal usage.
The devices also will have telephone modems or communications ports to allow users to get and send electronic mail or access the Internet.
Microsoft has tried before and failed to bring to market a stripped-down version of Windows, and many previous handheld computer devices have failed in the marketplace.
But Microsoft executives said the easy-to-use Windows 95 interface and the ability to swap information readily with desktop systems should boost sales of the new handheld computers.
And they say the operating system is a flexible platform that can be adapted to other Internet devices including "smart" telephones and television set-top boxes.
